ERT-VR: an immersive virtual reality system for emergency rescue training
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 13 May 2005

ERT-VR: an immersive virtual reality system for emergency rescue training

  • Lei Li1,
  • Maojun Zhang1,
  • Fangjiang Xu1 &
  • Shaohua Liu1 

Virtual Reality volume 8, pages194–197(2005)Cite this article

  • 447 Accesses

  • 9 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

Virtual reality technology offers a cost effective means to train emergency rescuers, which is an urgent task on account of the increasing terrorist acctivities. An immersive virtual reality system called ERT-VR is introduced. In ERT-VR, the display system based on stereoscopic projectors is used to train the emergency rescue commanders. The members of the operational teams use head-mounted display as the display system. The 3D scenario creator is the most important unit in ERT-VR. Instructors assign a specific training scenario to the trainees by using the scenario creator. Trainees take on the role of the characters in the training scenario and control their actions and ultimately the scenario outcomes. All the actions are recorded into the database system and can be replayed anytime. The potential of each trainee is evaluated by an expert system.

Introduction

Recent terrorist acctivities, increasing in a constantly changing global environment, are creating an ever-growing need for improved homeland security measures. Government agencies and forces need be better trained to finish the tasks of emergency rescue in unforeseen incidents such as terrorist threats, biological threats, and natural disasters (earthquakes or massively infectious diseases). Virtual reality technology offers enormous training potential with immersive trainees in a computer generated world [1]. It provides a cost effective environment to expose groups or individual employees to a variety of hazardous or critical experiences in a controlled manner [2–6].

With the help of virtual reality technology, we built an advanced training system called ERT-VR. This system initially focuses on the emergency rescue training for earthquakes. But it can be easily extended to be used in other emergency rescues, such as emergency rescues for mine and emergency rescues for city transportation.

ERT-VR is responsible for training the emergency rescue commanders, the operational teams consisting of three to six persons. A 3D scenario creator can be used to assign a specific training scenario to the trainees by instructors. Trainees take on the role of the characters in the training scenario and control their actions and ultimately the scenario outcomes. All the actions are recorded in the database system and can be replayed anytime. The potential of each trainee is evaluated by an expert system. Each trainee is assigned a credit based on the evaluation result of the outcome. As shown in Fig. 1, the training missions are set up by the emergency rescue experts from different fields, such as earthquake, mine, firefighting and so on. The missions will be used as the criteria for evaluating the training results of each trainee.

The training scenarios are created before each training exercise by the instructors. The training scenarios control the process of simulation. The simulation runs on the top of HLA/RTI. The simulation results are presented to the trainees. On the other hand, the interactions of the trainees are responded to by the 3D virtual environment system and this controls the run process of the simulation. The responses are sent to the simulation run unit which controls the run process of the simulation. The training results comprise the presentation of 3D virtual environments and the interaction of the trainees. The training results are used to evaluate the training. The training process is recorded in the simulation resource manager.

The components of ERT-VR

ERT-VR includes two primary units: team training system and commander training system. Figure 2 shows the hardware framework of ERT-VR. Currently, the team training system supports two teams simultaneously. Each team is composed of one to three trainees. The commander training system supports one commander at once.

Besides the team training system and commander training system, there are the simulation support platform and the simulation resource manager. The simulation support platform is responsible for running the simulation and sending the simulation results to the real-time rendering subsystem in the team training system and the commander training system. The simulation resource manager is responsible for storing and retrieving the simulation resource such as scenario databases and simulation models.

Figure 3 shows the hardware framework of the team training system. Each trainee wears a 5DT head-mounted display (HMD) display. CyberGlove is used to capture the motion of the trainees’ fingers. MotionStar tracks the motion of the trainees’ bodies. Each trainee is equipped with 12 sensors. As shown in Fig. 4, the motion tracking unit with 12 sensors can track the main parts of the body. In order to avoid the electromagnetic interferences, it is typically best to have any metal at least 20–30 ft away from the transmitters. Therefore, a minimal ceiling height of about 25 feet is ideal. In order to assure that the system can achieve the real-time responses to the trainees’ actions, we give each team a suite of MotionStar system. That way each team is equipped with one transmitter and 36 sensors. Each team is located in a room for which the minimum dimension of 40×40′ or greater is best. The two rooms are separated by 70–80 ft in order to avoid the interferences between the two transmitters.

The commander training system is located in a large room the dimension of which is 70′×70′. The commander sits in front of a cylindrical screen. The cylindrical screen is projected by three stereoscopic projectors. The commander wears a pair of active stereoscopic glasses. The audience sits behind the commander. The two rooms for the team training are located at the two sides of the large room, respectively, as shown in Fig. 5.

The team training system and the commander training system can run independently or simultaneously. If the team training system and the commander training system run simultaneously, the avatar of each trainee will be displayed on the cylindrical screen in the commander training system. Therefore, the commander can monitor and command the training of all team members.

If the team training system and the commander training system are run independently, the avatar of each trainee is driven by an artifical intelligent entity. The commander issues the commands by means of his voice. The voice is recognized by IBM Viavoice. The avatars respond to the commands and finish the tasks assigned by the commander.

The architecture of ERT-VR

ERT-VR is divided into four layers: scenario layer, application layer, engine layer and support layer, as shown in Fig. 6. The training scenario creator is located in the scenario layer. The training scenario creator is the brain of ERT-VR. It is an integrated environment for the creation of interactive computer generated training scenarios. It provides all the tools necessary for the training departments to create training scenarios from libraries of scenario objects and for trainees and instructors to interact with these training scenarios. No specialist computer generated scenario skills are required and is designed for use by trained professionals.

The training scenario creator comprises a scenario-scripting tool that allows instructors to create and edit unique and complex training scenarios as well as a run-time environment that allows the instructor and trainees to interact with the scenario.

Training scenarios are created from libraries of characters, objects sets and props. Sets form the 3D world in which the scenario takes place. Typically environment elements for the set can be controlled,e.g. time of day, lighting levels, weather etc. The instructor can then add static props to this world to complete the scenario environment.

Once the scenario environment has been established, the characters and objects are added. Characters and objects have pre-defined behaviours which can be triggered such as people running, trains moving or audio generated. The instructor then scripts the behaviours of all the characters and objects in the scenario by linking the triggers for their behaviours to scenario events such as the behaviour of another character or object, an instructor or trainee command or at some predetermined point in the scenario.

Characters and objects can have as many distinct behaviours as necessary and each of these behaviours can be as complex as required by the particular scenario. Triggers for each behaviour can be also be multi-state requiring exact scenario conditions to be satisfied using Boolean AND/OR/NOT logic.

The system managers will manipulate the training scenario creator to create a scenario, which plays the part of an exercise assigned to the trainee. The scenario will be sent to the commander training system, the team training system and the training evaluation system.

The commander training system, the team training system, the simulation modeling system, the training recording and replaying system and the training evaluation system are located in the application layer. The simulation modeling system provides models (such as 3D scene models, virtual sufferers, avatars and so on) for the training scenario creator. The training recording and replaying system is responsible for recording the training process and replaying the previous training process at any point of time. The training evaluation system is responsible for evaluating the training quality based on the recorded training process. The rules of the evaluation will be provided by the emergency rescue experts.

The components of the engine layer include IBM ViaVoice and the visual simulation engine. The visual simulation engine (such as Vega) is the heart of ERT-VR. It provides the 3D visual scenes and 3D directional sounds for the commander training system, the team training system and the training recording and replaying system. In the support layer, there are HLA/RTI, and the simulation resource manager. The simulation resource manager is based on Oracle DBMS.

Conclusions

ERT-VR was initially designed for the earthquake emergency rescues. But the framework is general and can be used for other emergency rescues. The training scenario creator is the brain of ERT-VR. The visual simulation engine is the heart of ERT-VR. In the current status, ERT-VR simultaneously supports one commander and six team members. We will extend the number of users in our further work.
